unnormalised: Someone asked me how safe are online transactions in India, especially using UPI. Well, it's a mixed bag, honestly. On one hand, UPI's incredibly convenient, right? Scanning a QR code or just using someone’s mobile no. to pay is so much faster than digging out your wallet. Plus, the NPCI keeps pushing for better security features. But, like anything digital, there are risks. You hear stories about people getting scammed out of ₹5000 or even ₹50000 using fake UPI apps or phishing links.
normalised: Someone asked me how safe are online transactions in India, especially using U-P-I. Well, it's a mixed bag, honestly. On one hand, U-P-I's incredibly convenient, right? Scanning a Q-R code or just using someone's mobile number to pay is so much faster than digging out your wallet. Plus, the N-P-C-I keeps pushing for better security features. But, like anything digital, there are risks. You hear stories about people getting scammed out of rupee five thousand or even rupee fifty thousand using fake U-P-I apps or phishing links.

unnormalised: The biggest risk, I think, is just plain carelessness. People sharing their UPI PIN (which you should NEVER do!), or clicking on suspicious links they get in SMS. I got a message once claiming I'd won ₹1000000 from a lottery, and all I had to do was enter my UPI PIN. Obviously, I didn’t! And don't even get me started on the apps that ask for way too many permissions. Why does a flashlight app need access to my contacts? Makes you wonder what they're really up to.

unnormalised: So, is it safe? Relatively. Using strong passwords, keeping your UPI PIN secret, being wary of suspicious links, and sticking to reputable e-commerce sites (like Amazon or Flipkart) are musts. And always, ALWAYS double-check the payment details before you hit that "Pay Now" button, especially if you're transferring a large amount, like Rs. 25000 or more. Better safe than sorry!
